comments.commentBody: That's an interesting view em.  Wonder if those tanks have a hidden homing beacon in them, or some self destruct feature in case of capture???

That is football, no?  The logo is a warrior.  The point is that the old nickname and logo was about:  highly respected and fierce.  Not all Indians would the logo and name suggest, just the fierce ones.  Do you want squaws?  How about Washington Sachems (old Indian wise men)?

"very strong historical status"

It's a professional football team - a package of merchandising and televised entertainment. It is very, very far from having actual historical significance.

Now do people see why graduate students (and other non-tenured faculty) have been craving some level of joint bargaining / unionization? Grad students are generally required to teach as part of their training. But they are rarely taught to teach; they are generally paid little more than a reduction in their own tuition; and they may well be put in harm's way, with little to no legal recourse.

I took my university's mandated training course on how to handle students in distress. We were told that the university police would only come and remove the student if he or she answered "yes" to the question "Do you want to harm yourself or others" and that asking that question was our responsibility.
We can suggest to a student that he or she go for counseling, but that is as much as we are allowed to do.
I don't know about anywhere but where I am, but I can have disruptive students removed by security. The right of all to an education trumps that of any one student.

This piece raises more questions than it answers.
1) Faculty members aren't trained therapists. The advice given thus seems odd on many levels. I can't even imagine asking a student: "Do you have a plan to harm yourself or others?" What is even the point of such a question since anyone with such a plan is unlikely to answer in the affirmative (as the student pointed out)?
2) If the student is disruptive in class to the point where his/her behavior makes it hard for the other students to learn, couldn't that student have been told by the faculty supervisor that the behavior had to change and that she (the faculty supervisor, not the graduate instructor) would drop him from the course if it didn't (instead of inflicting continuing angst on a graduate student instructor and the other students in the class)?
3) Why didn't the faculty supervisor (or another, full-time, tenured faculty member) take over the course rather than sit outside and keep watch while a graduate student - "a shy, soft-spoken young woman working on her master of fine arts in poetry"! - is in a frightening situation?
4) Why was the "poet instructor" present during the "interrogation"? What if the undergraduate student had pulled a gun and the instructor had been hurt?
5) Once the student mentioned he went to a shooting range, couldn't campus police have a) made inquiries about the student's gun ownership and b) posted an officer or security guard outside or in the classroom?
Stop equating human beings with animals. Just stop it.

Mr. Rangel is a crook and entitled DC denizen. Hopefully all voters (Black, white, hispanic, green, whatever) will send him back to his 3 apartments. Newly arrived white voters are probably the last people to vote for him.
Age and excessive exertion in the last few months took their toll.  But these fateful moments open the door for new teams and new pride.  Spain will come back, but let Chile  rise!

Well stated and thank you for delivering this clarification on the term 'football'.

I presume, you will now be chastised by the Europeans for such blasphemy.

Bingo.  Plus if you go up to Sydney "footy" isn't even Australian Rules anymore.  It's rugby, as I discovered one day when watching "The Footy Show" and neither Essendon nor any of the other footy clubs I know were featured.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_(word)

The etymology of the word Football apparently isn't clear cut.

Association Football is called Soccer in Australia as well in many other nations around the world. This is not unique to the USA.

First point the term football came about to distinguish sports played on horseback and those on foot. The fact that a particular code doesn’t involve kicking a ball is irrelevant.

Second point there are other codes of football such as Australian Rules Football that used the term Football that had their rules codified well before Soccer.

Soccer has no more right to the term football than any other code. It is simply the case that the term football describes the most popular code of football played in that particular country or region. If someone talks about football in Melbourne I know they are talking about Aussy Rules. If I am in New York and someone says football I know they are referring to Gridiron and if I’m in London its Soccer.

As someone who grew up in Apartheid South Africa and stayed in the US because of that, I cannot imagine, even back then, that any professional team, (none existed back then, that I know of) being brash enough to call itself the "Blackskins", and saying this was a tribute to Zulu, Xhosa, Basuto (offshoot of Zulu) warrior 'aboriginal' South Africans. True aboriginals were of course the Khoi and the Khoi San (or San). If one looks at the facial image representing the "Indians", it is clearly derogatory. The "Chiefs", at least, can claim to take the anglicized name for Tribal leaders. I was always bemused by US espousers of sanctions against S.Africa (albeit justifiable in the face of Apartheid) and the total silince (until recently) about the equivalent treatment in this country of native peoples. So called "Tribal Homelands", Reservations, etc. are just euphemisms for what were called "Bantustans" (derived from Bantu, a language group) under Verwoerd.
If I knew the name for an equivalent language-ethnic group I'd suggest something similar for the way Native Americans have been marginalized and segregated.
Tired, old arguments with nothing useful to offer. Just because you see something one way doesn't mean everyone else does.

As a 60 year old sports fan, I find this fight to be PC silly and just piling on. When I think of monikers for teams I either root for or against, I think of the personalities, the wins and tough losses. Shen I think of the Mets, I think of 1969, Tom Seaver, Jerry Grote, Lenny Dystrra, and David Wright. Also if you asked 100 what the Mets name means many wouldnt know what a "Met" is.
When I root against the Cowboys I think of the star on the helmet, Bob Hayes, Rodger the Dodger, To tall Jones and Emmitt Smith. When I focus on the REDSKINS, I slightly remember Sonny Jurgenson, and 72- 40 thrashing in 1966 and Larry Brown. Political Correctiveness has run amuck. I might be a minority here. But with song lyrics and movie violence showing more disdain towards ANY group, it is a wasted platform and soapbox to stand on
how would that fix this? have you seen where the money was spent here? take a trip to Detroit and tell me what you think?

Here's a simple solution: restore higher tax rates on the rich and corporations. Put them back to where they were in the 1960s. A fundamental problem is that corporations and the rich have managed to get their taxes cut in the past 40 years, shifting the burden of paying for decent wages and benefits onto the struggling middle class. We're missing the forest for the trees with all this discussion of hybrid pension plans and bankruptcy proceedings.

The Supreme Court decided 5-4 that money equals speech and at this point there's no way around that. We could easily change our laws so that we ban political TV ads and have a 3 month election cycle as they currently do in Britain. This would remove over 80% of the money, wouldn't cost the taxpayers a dime a would save our democracy. Oh well. a person can dream.

A rate of return of 6.75% seems extremely high for a pension plan, which should properly be funded with conservative relatively risk-free investments. If the expected rate of return for public pensions has actually been 7.9% it's no wonder so many are now underfunded. To reach that level would require a relatively high amount of risk. When those risks don't all come through, underfunding results, which must be covered by extremely unwilling taxpayers. Of course, a lower expected rate of return would also require the tax payers to pay more, but at least it would be done honestly.
You're right - it doesn't matter.

I'm disappointed. Britain should have said no thank you, the Queen isn't available until you get out of Tibet and the South China Sea. Our economy is doing just fine, at least most Chinese people seem to think so when they buy London apartments.

The situation in Iraq is best compared to the practice of dueling in the United States. Men engaged in duels, which, for modern Americans, would made no sense at all – nevertheless, dueling continued well into the 19th century. In fact, Abraham Lincoln was involved a duel in 1842.

The duel between Shia and Suni is a feature of Iraqi culture - not, as we see it, a defect or aberration. It makes no sense to us, but for them, the conflict is an unavoidable obligation.

Our inability to understand the way the current conflict is progressing, is simply a reflection of our total lack of understanding of Iraqi culture. Our presumption that they really want to live like us, is very off base.

By suppling modern weapons to the current Iraqi government, we only make things deadlier; and many of the weapons we supply will end in the hands of ISIS, which is not a good thing.

It's time for us to get 100% out of Iraq.

They are all busy looking for "potential terrorists" in the USA while the real terrorists are methodically advancing in broad day light, often publishing their goals and aspirations to the world via social media channels.
Nobody saw this coming?   CIA?  Military intelligence?  The press?  The 5000 embassy employees?  The drone fleets? Please explain.

It sounds forced, but when my son attended a boys-only Y camp (Camp Becket) in the Berkshires for a few summers, he did internalize some of their long-time mottos:
Play the game
Manners maketh the man
Peace through understanding
I can and I will
Each for all—all for each
Better faithful than famous
Help the other fellow

To this day he believes in these. Two months free from the body focused scrum CAN make a difference. I attended a day camp through age 14. We did not have dances or socials and I consider that a huge gift: a couple more summers without boy-girl social pressures.

BTW: If a student is "forced" to see a mental health professional, he/she can just stonewall. No one can "make" them talk or confess, and it is not an interrogation, is an interview. The school needs mental health law consultation, NOT creative writing teachers involvement with this.
It's time to evacuate every American from Iraq.
Keep the Iraqi government stabilized? That boat left the dock a long time ago.

The 1994 Budapest Memorandum signed by the US, UK, Ukraine and Russia guaranteed the territorial integrity of Ukraine and its freedom from economic and political coercion from Russia.  The US has a commitment to help Ukraine in this matter and by this agreement would be obliged to assist Ukraine.  The fact that actions by Russia in Ukraine are destabilizing all of Europe, would suggest that NATO intervention could be justified by its members.

Re: woodsbeldau comments.
I would like to re-phrase your comments:
The 1994 Budapest Memorandum signed by the US,UK and Russia guaranteed the territorial integrity of Ukraine and its freedom from economic and political coercion from the US(or NATO).
The Russians have a commitment to help the Ukraine in this matter and by this agreement would be obliged to assist the Ukraine.
The fact that actions by the US is destabilizing all of Europe, would suggest that UN intervention be justified by its members.
Let's be honest.

If the rebel-separatists reject Poroshenko's ceasefire offer then that means that Putin also rejects the offer. One does not act without the other's approval, why pretend otherwise.

The West should offer NATO membership to Ukraine NOW. Ukraine wants to eventually be a part of NATO's democratic freedoms instead of Moscow's growing totalitarian regime anyway.......Call Putin's bluff.

So far, no one and nothing's stopping Putin from doing as he pleases. The bully on the block is still winning.

Really.... Huh. I truly find the timeline of Trade 5 for one US Soldier Bowe Bergadhl , the investigation of Pres/Commander and Chief Obama and State Department Regarding Their decided Failure and  Neglect to Protect USA Ambassador and 3 other Americans....  Seems to me that the Political Value of American Life is But a political Pawn show with this administration.  NOW, all of a "Politically Convenient time" , the Bad Guy is apprehended? Pretty  coincidental.

No use for blaming the company. It is the government that to be blamed. Pakistan and its leaders still live ion the cave age. They wish their citizens stay in the dark age to be manipulated. That is what its military leaders did for the last 67 years. Civil leaders are at the mercy of military radicals. we have seen it during the fight against terrorism after 9/11. Newaz Sharif and his cabinets need to wake up and bring civility against blasphemy and similar laws.

I agree. If a student starts crying, that is an invitation to intervene. A mental health professional would have known this, and at least encourage the conversation. But the case here was that the college wanted to protect themselves, not help this young man.
